aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident in Baltimore, Maryland
The accident occurred in Baltimore, Maryland.
The accident occurred on February 7, 2020, at 04:15 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a Cessna 208.
The defining event was a collision during takeoff/land.
The flight was conducted under Part 135: Air taxi & commuter - Non-scheduled.
The accident number was ERA20CA095.
The aircraft registration was N988FX.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
There was 1 person with no injuries.
The pilot was conducting an instrument landing system approach.
The approach was conducted in night instrument meteorological conditions.
The pilot was using the autopilot for the approach to the destination airport.
The pilot disengaged the autopilot when he had the runway and airport lighting system in view.
The pilot heard a sound as he approached the runway.
The pilot thought the airplane had hit a bird.
The pilot felt the airplane pitch up.
The pilot increased engine power.
The pilot pitched down to reach the runway.
The pilot landed the aircraft.
The pilot taxied to the ramp.
The pilot saw a large piece of an approach light caught on the right main landing gear.
Further examination revealed the empennage sustained substantial damage.
Further examination revealed the right horizontal stabilizer sustained substantial damage.
Further examination revealed the right wing strut sustained substantial damage.
Further examination revealed the front cargo pod sustained substantial damage.
The operator reported the airplane had struck four approach light towers.
The operator reported the airplane had struck a localizer antenna.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident to be the pilot's failure to maintain clearance from the approach lights during an instrument approach.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Baltimore, Maryland

## Date & Time: 
February 7, 2020, 04:15 Local

## Aircraft:
Cessna 208

## Defining Event:
Collision during takeoff/land

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 135: Air taxi & commuter - Non-scheduled

## Accident Number:
ERA20CA095

## Registration:
N988FX

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
1 None

## Analysis

The pilot was conducting an instrument landing system approach in night instrument meteorological conditions. The pilot was using the autopilot for the approach to the destination airport and disengaged it when he had the runway and airport lighting system in view. The pilot reported that, as he approached the runway, he heard a sound and thought the airplane had hit a bird. He felt the airplane pitch up, so he increased engine power and pitched down to reach the runway. After the pilot landed and taxied to the ramp, he saw that a large piece of an approach light was caught on the right main landing gear. Further examination revealed that the empennage, right horizontal stabilizer, right wing strut, and front cargo pod had sustained substantial damage. The operator reported that the airplane had struck four approach light towers and a localizer antenna.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:

The pilot's failure to maintain clearance from the approach lights during an instrument approach.

---
